body: WANDERING the Kia or Hyundai showrooms at the Plaza Auto Mall in Brooklyn, a potential buyer sees no signs that the Korean auto industry is being shaken to its foundations. Sales in the United States are growing and so are cash payments from manufacturers to dealers to pump up sales. ''You can get up to $3,000 off a Kia Sephia, which makes it about
geo_facet: FAR EAST, SOUTH AND SOUTHEAST ASIA AND PACIFIC AREAS
title: AUTOS ON FRIDAY/International; Asia Aftershocks in U.S. Showrooms

body: Maybe Jenny Cavilleri didn't die of a mysterious disease. Maybe she got divorced and moved to Greenwich, where she is alive and well and playing the piano in a chamber music trio. Janet Sussman Gartner loves Beethoven, Bach and the Beatles. She bites her nails. And, at 60, this mother of three still enjoys putting Harvard preppies in their place.
title: Liberties; Is Janet Jenny?

body: A four-year effort to refinance the mortgage of the 65-unit prewar cooperative building in the Midwood section of Brooklyn had been unsuccessful. Like many other buildings that were converted to co-ops at the end of the mid-1980's real estate boom, the Brooklyn co-op had more renters than owners. But for this building, and others like it, securing
title: Residential Real Estate ; Co-op Refinancing Easier in New Market

body: Tottenville captured its first Public School Athletic League title yesterday, defeating its Staten Island rival Curtis, 24-22, in front of 2,000 at Midwood Field in Brooklyn. It was the seventh time in 13 years that a team from Staten Island won the P.S.A.L. title. Tottenville (11-2) was sparked by the senior Cassel Smith, who rushed for 161 of his
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Tottenville Wins Title In P.S.A.L.

body: At first, it appeared to be a simple case of a heart attack. John Morales, a 61-year-old school aide who worked in the locker room at Midwood High School in Brooklyn and had a history of heart problems, collapsed in a school hallway on Monday morning and died in the hospital on Tuesday, the police said. It became a criminal matter on Tuesday after
title: 16-Year-Old Is Under Arrest In Death of Teacher's Aide

body: Christopher R. Lynn was the most unpopular man in Brooklyn last week, at least among the borough's community boards. In district after district, Mr. Lynn, the Transportation Commissioner, was under fire for what critics described as an autocratic management style, characterized by a refusal to consult or advise the boards. The eye of the political
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Speed Humps That Divide

body: Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani began the last week of campaigning yesterday with a foray into the heart of Ruth W. title: THE 1997 ELECTIONS: THE CAMPAIGNING; Giuliani Goes After Voters In Messinger's Stronghold

body: LAWYERS who represent New York City co-ops and condominiums are being bombarded with calls from anxious clients after a Criminal Court judge declined last month to dismiss criminal complaints against three members of a Brooklyn co-op board charged with violating the city's Window Guard Law. The charges were filed after an inspection of the building
title: YOUR HOME; Boards Reviewing Liability

body: On some days, Kelly Bunkley, a prim 17-year-old, slips into the health-resource room at Edward R. Murrow High School in Brooklyn, where she quietly asks for a free condom. She says her visits to the room on the second floor, where condoms are kept locked in a file cabinet, give her a powerful weapon she can pass along to help a former schoolmate
title: When Sex Is Just a Matter of Fact; To High School Students, Free Condoms Seem Normal, Not Debatable

body: THE sharp rhythms of Brooklynese broke the silence on Gold Street, where a family lounged on the stoop of their building. The sights and sounds were enough to baffle Ralph Hoetmer and his friend Daniel Gulpers, as they walked along the dimly lighted side street off the Fulton Mall. ''If we spoke that way on our exams we would get a really low
title: About New York; Dutch Treat: Hanging Out In 'Breukelen'

body: A Brooklyn judge has ruled that board members of cooperative apartment buildings can face criminal charges for actions by the board, a decision that has alarmed many volunteers who serve on co-op boards throughout the city. The case in which the ruling was made involves misdemeanor criminal charges filed against a co-op, and against several
title: Co-op Board Members Fret Over Ruling on Liability

body: To the Editor: Your article ''The Newest Power Broker in New York'' (Aug. 31) accurately chronicles the perennial power struggle in our public school system. But there is another and indeed a critical dimension to this power struggle, and it is about diversity. As the student body in our public schools reflects the growing immigrant population in
title: Of Power Brokers and Race Cards; Educational Establishment Ignores Ethnic Realities

body: Preps After a pre-game ceremony honoring Frank Bertino, the school's most successful coach, Riverdale (1-1) routed Horace Mann, 30-0. John Reid rushed for two touchdowns and completed a halfback-option pass to quarterback Elliott Appel. Bertino (247-47-6), who died last month at 77, guided Riverdale to 13 Ivy Prep School league titles and 17
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL; Riverdale Routs Horace Mann After Ceremony for Coach

body: THE sole creation from the House of Frania Blum is strikingly simple. In 1945, Mrs. Blum sewed a blue and white peasant dress with puffed sleeves, a cinched waist and the slightly rough look of something stitched by halting hands. It has no price tag, because it is priceless. Mrs. Blum calls it her Liberation Dress, the only dress she ever made and
title: About New York; Simple Dress In Spotlight, Triumphantly

body: A 70-year-old Brooklyn man has taken the first step toward filing a lawsuit against the city in connection with an altercation with a police officer from the 70th Precinct that left him with a badly injured hip, the man's lawyer said yesterday. The man, Mario Saccavino, ran from his house on East 14th Street in the Midwood section after officers
title: 70th Precinct Faces Lawsuit In New Arrest And Dispute

title: Schools Often Turn Bathrooms Into Classrooms

body: One minute he was acting as the city's peacemaker, bringing together Jews and Arabs for a hastily arranged handshake a few doors away from an apartment where bombs were found in Brooklyn. The next moment he was the quintessential urban politician, slapping the backs of startled strangers on the street, signing autographs, posing for pictures with
title: Slapping Backs and Soothing Strains, Giuliani Takes a Tour

body: ''I BELIEVE in inoculating my students with both creationism and evolution,'' Trenton Hamidan, a seventh-grade science teacher, said last week. Faith in creationism leads us to respect for God and to a frame of
title: In a 'Haven,' No Rap, Cola or Long Nails

body: Four years ago, Anthony D. Weiner cruised easily to victory in the Democratic primary for the City Council race, facing only token opposition. title: Congress a Backdrop to Council Race

body: A semiautomatic pistol accidentally fired yesterday as a 15-year-old girl held it in an apartment in Brooklyn, and the bullet struck a 12-year-old friend in the chest, the police said. The wounded child was taken to Kings County Hospital Center, where she was listed in stable condition, Officer Cheryl Cox, a Police Department spokeswoman, said. The
title: Girl Shoots Friend In a Gun Accident

title: Study Backs Tunnel to Replace the Gowanus

title: Klezmer Amid the Rockers

title: Class Notes From a Skipped Generation

body: Miro has always craved exercise. He is an 8-year-old Saluki, a breed of dog related to the greyhound. But when he moved to Carroll Gardens from Midwood, where he had a yard, four years ago, something inside of him died. ''He kind of wilted,'' said Alyssa Bonilla, who owns Miro. ''He didn't have enough space to run.'' Now he does. Two weeks ago,
title: Official Run Is a First for Brooklyn Dogs

title: Class Notes

body: TO express joy on a festive Jewish holiday, it is traditional to wear something new. body: It was lucky for Ward Melville High School that Jonathan William Plaue chose to enter the Westinghouse Science competition. Mr. Plaue, 17, a senior at the school in Setauket, L.I., blended asphalt and ash to see if it would make a viable road-paving substance. His question: Would it be an economical and environmentally safe way to dispose of ash?

title: It's New York, but Not Really
